references:
1) Performance Degradation of Incomplete Client Participation:
As shown in TableÂ 1, a distinct and non-trivial decline in performance is observed for FedAvg when confronted with incomplete client participation.
As the value of sğ‘ s increases, it signifies progressively more incomplete client participation.
Upon comparing scenarios with s=0ğ‘ 0s=0 and s=4ğ‘ 4s=4 , a significant reduction in test accuracy becomes apparent, reaching up to 27.44%percent27.4427.44\% for MNIST and 25%percent2525\% for CIFAR10.
It is noteworthy that such performance degradation is also contingent on data heterogeneity, denoted by pğ‘p. In the case of IID data (p=10ğ‘10p=10), only a negligible decrease in test accuracy is observed. For instance, in MNIST, the accuracy slightly drops from 92.69%percent92.6992.69\% for s=0ğ‘ 0s=0 to 92.62%percent92.6292.62\% for s=4ğ‘ 4s=4.
In CIFAR10, the accuracy decreases from 81.12%percent81.1281.12\% for s=0ğ‘ 0s=0 to 77.78%percent77.7877.78\% for s=4ğ‘ 4s=4.
These results empirically validate the worst-case analysis in TheoremÂ 1 and serve as the primary motivation for the development of SA-FL.

references:
I. Improved test accuracy.
In TableÂ 2 and Â 3, we show the test accuracy improvement of our ğ–²ğ– ğ–¥ğ– ğ–±ğ–¨ğ–²ğ– ğ–¥ğ– ğ–±ğ–¨\mathsf{SAFARI}Â algorithm compared with that of FedAvg in standard FL.
In TableÂ 2, we can observe that even with a few server participation with a probability of 0.20.20.2, there is a non-negligible improvement in test accuracy.
In TableÂ 3,
the key observation is that, with a small amount of auxiliary data at the server, there is a significant increase of test accuracy for our ğ–²ğ– ğ–¥ğ– ğ–±ğ–¨ğ–²ğ– ğ–¥ğ– ğ–±ğ–¨\mathsf{SAFARI}Â algorithm.
For example, with only 505050 data samples at the server (0.1%percent0.10.1\% of the total training data), there is a 16.65%percent16.6516.65\% test accuracy increase.
With 100010001000 data samples, the improvement reaches 31.07%percent31.0731.07\%.
This verifies the effectiveness of our SA-FL framework and our ğ–²ğ– ğ–¥ğ– ğ–±ğ–¨ğ–²ğ– ğ–¥ğ– ğ–±ğ–¨\mathsf{SAFARI}Â algorithm.
Another observation is that for nearly homogeneous case (e.g., from p=10ğ‘10p=10 to p=5ğ‘5p=5), there is no statistical difference with or without auxiliary data at the server (denoted by â€˜-â€™ in TableÂ 3.
This is consistent with the previous observations of negligible degradation in cases with homogeneous data across clients.
